byline.contributor: Frances Robles and Hannah Berkeley Cohen contributed reporting.

abstract: Speech delivered by Pres Obama in Havana, Cuba, is both strikingly personal and unusually forthright treatment of subject of race and racism; reactions of Cubans to speech show degree to which their affection for Obama is informed by identity as well as by Obama's policies, and degree to which race and racism remains unresolved issue in society, despite promises of revolution.
snippet: In a speech in Havana, the president noted America’s and Cuba’s similar struggles with racism, spotlighting an issue the Cuban government says is settled....
lead_paragraph: In a speech in Havana, the president noted America’s and Cuba’s similar struggles with racism, spotlighting an issue the Cuban government says is settled.

headline.main: Cuba Says It Has Solved Racism. Obama Isn’t So Sure.
headline.print_headline: Obama Looks Past Cuba’s Post-Racial Veneer
